title: How to Make Apple Chips

steps.headline: Wash the apples.
steps.description: Run them under cold water until the water running off of them is completely clear. The water helps remove dirt and chemical residue. Once they are washed, pat them dry.

steps.headline: Peel the apple skins for a crispier chip.
steps.description: Use a vegetable peeler or paring knife to remove the skin. Start at the top of the apple and move the blade in a clockwise motion down and around the circumference of the apple. The skin should come off easily and in one big ribbon. Remove the skin if you want a chewier chip. If you’re looking to make really crispy chips, leave the skin on. Keep your thumbs out of the way so you don’t cut yourself on the peeler or knife.

steps.headline: Core the apples with an apple peeler.
steps.description: Insert the corer tool in the center of the apple. To loosen the apple core, just push down and twist the tool. Then, use your hands to pull out the apple core. You may not get all the apple core and seeds out. If there’s anything left behind, use a paring knife to gently scrape the seeds off of the apple.

steps.headline: Cut the apples into thin, uniform slices.
steps.description: You want them all to be the same thickness. Slice horizontally, parallel to the stem, and aim for roughly 0.125 inches (0.32 cm) thickness. A mandolin or meat slicer works best, but a knife works as well if you go slowly.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 200 °F (93 °C).
steps.description: Let your oven heat while you prepare the apples to speed up the whole process. Set a timer to let you know when the oven is ready.

steps.headline: Place the apple slices on a metal cooling rack.
steps.description: Lay your wire rack on top of a baking sheet to capture any dripping juice. Then, spread the apples evenly and don’t let them overlap. You need them to be exposed to properly air dry. However, it’s alright if the slices touch. If you don’t have a metal cooling rack, you can use any other heat resistant platter, like a pizza screen or baking sheet. However, you should try to aim for a rack or platter with holes for better airflow.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the apples with powdered sugar and cinnamon.
steps.description: A little bit of sweetness will add a lot of flavor to your apple chips. Just pinch some sugar and or cinnamon and sprinkle it evenly over the tops of the apple slices. If sugar is too sweet, consider using honey as an alternative.

steps.headline: Bake the apples for 1 hour.
steps.description: Place the tray with the apple slices in the oven carefully. Leave the oven cracked open slightly to vent the moisture from the apples. If your oven doesn’t stay open slightly on its own, use a wooden spoon to wedge it open. Be careful with the oven. Use heat protection and keep children and pets away from the oven. Set a timer to remind you when 1 hour has gone by.

steps.headline: Flip the apples with a spatula.
steps.description: Leave the oven on and remove the apples from the oven. Then, use a spatula to flip each chip on its other side. However, if you're using a non-mesh or wire baking sheet, where air can't escape the apples from below, turn them every 30-45 minutes.

steps.headline: Bake the apples for about 1 more hour.
steps.description: This may take a little longer or shorter than 1 hour. The thicker the apples, the longer it may take. It should take about 1 hour for the apple edges to curl up slightly.

steps.headline: Let the apples cool for 1 hour.
steps.description: If you want crispy chips, let the chips cool in the oven. But, if you want chewier chips, set the chips to cool outside the oven. Either way, make sure to turn off the oven. Keep in mind that before cooling, the apples may be rubbery. Don’t worry! They will crisp up as they cool.

steps.headline: Store the chips in an airtight container.
steps.description: Keep your apple chips in a cool and dry place. You can keep them stored for up to 2 weeks before having to throw them out. Enjoy!

steps.headline: Line a plate with parchment paper.
steps.description: Use a microwave-safe plate to keep your microwave clean. If you don’t have parchment paper, use a paper towel instead.

steps.headline: Place the apple slices on the parchment paper.
steps.description: Spread the apples evenly in a single layer. Don’t let the apples overlap. Overlapping slices will interfere with the drying process. It’s okay if the apple edges are touching lightly.

steps.headline: Microwave the apples for 4.5 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: It should take 4.5 to 5 minutes for the edges of the apples to start curling. However, depending on the microwave and slice thickness, it may take shorter or longer for the apples to start curling. Once they start curling, remove them from the microwave. Watch the apples while they are microwaving.

steps.headline: Flip the apples with a spatula.
steps.description: Make sure to turn over every apple slice. Make sure they aren’t overlapped once you flip them. Do this step as quickly as you can. You don’t want the slices to lose too much heat.

steps.headline: Microwave the apples for 1 more minute.
steps.description: Depending on how thick your apple slices are, this may take more or less time. Remove the apples after the 1-minute mark or once the edges curl more.

steps.headline: Let the apples cool for about 10 minutes.
steps.description: By this time, the apples should be pretty crisp and dry. Serve them immediately and enjoy!
